The information that Plk1 regulates centrosome function and its activity is down-regulated after irradiation led us to explore its effects on radiation-induced inhibition of centrosome separation.Nek2 is a cell cycle-regulated serine/threonine kinase of the NIMA (never in mitosis A) family (29Fry A.M. Schultz S.J. Bartek J. Nigg E.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 12899-12905Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Nek2 is located at the centrosome and has been implicated in centrosome splitting in mammalian cells (30Fry A.M. Meraldi P. Nigg E.A. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 470-481Crossref PubMed Scopus (338) Google Scholar, 31Fry A.M. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 6184-6194Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar). There are two alternatively spliced forms of Nek2, Nek2A, and Nek2B (32Hames R.S. Fry A.M. Biochem. J. 2002; 361: 77-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Nek2A is elevated in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle, whereas Nek2B is present during S, G2, and mitosis (32Hames R.S. Fry A.M. Biochem. J. 2002; 361: 77-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Nek2A, but not Nek2B, stimulates centrosome disjunction and is required for the formation of bipolar mitotic spindles (33Faragher A.J. Fry A.M. Mol. Boil. Cell. 2003; 14: 2876-2889Crossref PubMed Scopus (0) Google Scholar). Nek2A forms a complex with protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) and the centrosomal Nek2-associated protein, C-Nap1 (34Helps N.R. Luo X. Barker H.M. Cohen P.T. Biochem. J. 2000; 349: 509-518Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 35Fry A.M. Mayor T. Meraldi P. Stierhof Y.D. Tanaka K. Nigg E.A. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 141: 1563-1574Crossref PubMed Scopus (351) Google Scholar). Nek2A can phosphorylate itself, PP1, and C-Nap1, whereas PP1 can dephosphorylate both Nek2A and C-Nap1 (34Helps N.R. Luo X. Barker H.M. Cohen P.T. Biochem. J. 2000; 349: 509-518Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar). Coexpression of PP1 with Nek2A suppresses centrosome splitting, whereas ectopic expression of inhibitor protein 2, a physiological inhibitor of PP1, stimulating splitting (36Meraldi P. Nigg E.A. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 3749-3757Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 37Eto M. Elliott E. Prickett T.D. Brautigan D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 44013-44020Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). We have shown that irradiated cells fail to activate Nek2 and that radiation inhibits the centrosome splitting induced by overexpression of Nek2, suggesting that inhibition of centrosome separation as a DNA damage response is mechanistically linked to Nek2 (15Fletcher L. Cerniglia G.J. Nigg E.A. Yen T.Y. Muschel R.J. Radiat. Res. 2004; 162: 128-135Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). However, the upstream regulator of Nek2 in this DNA damage checkpoint pathway remained to be determined.Here we show that a constitutively active mutant of Plk1 can override the inhibition of centrosome separation after ionizing radiation. The inhibition of centrosome separation is dependent on ATM but not on Chk2 or Chk1. Plk1 interacts with Nek2 in vivo and can phosphorylate Nek2 in vitro. Furthermore, inhibition of Plk1 by siRNA prevents Nek2-induced centrosome splitting. Our data indicate that Plk1 acts upstream of Nek2 in the signaling pathway, which leads to the inhibition of centrosome separation after IR.MATERIALS AND METHODSCell Culture and Cell Treatment—HeLa and U2OS cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 1% penicillin and streptomycin. Centrin-GFP-Hela cell line was maintained in selective media containing G418 (200 μg/ml, Mediatech). Tetracycline-inducible GFP-Nek2A-U2OS cell line is a gift from Dr. Andrew Fry (University of Leicester, UK), and maintained in selective media containing Zeocin (200 μg/ml, Invitrogen) and hygromycin B (100 μg/ml, Roche Applied Science) (33Faragher A.J. Fry A.M. Mol. Boil. Cell. 2003; 14: 2876-2889Crossref PubMed Scopus (0) Google Scholar). Tetracycline (2 μg/ml) was added to the culture medium to induce and maintain expression of GFP-Nek2A.Cells were synchronized in G1/S using a thymidine block (2 mm, Sigma) for 16 h. Cells were then released from the block by washing three times with Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum and refed with Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum and thymidine/deoxycytidine (2.5 × 10-5 m). After 3 h, cells were irradiated using a Shepherd Mark 1 Model 68A cesium irradiator. Caffeine (Sigma) was added at a concentration of 3 mm. Cycloheximide was added at a concentration of 10 μg/ml. Proteasome inhibitor MG132 (Sigma) was added at a concentration of 20 μm.Flow Cytometry Analysis—Cell pellets were resuspended in citrate buffer and stained with propidium iodide as described (38Fletcher L. Muschel R.J. Radiat. Res. 2003; 159: 604-611Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). Data were acquired with Becton Dickinson FACScan flow cytometer and analyzed using CellQuest (Version 2.01.2).Transfection—Myc-tagged wild type (wt) Plk1, kinase inactive mutant K82R and constitutively active mutant T210D Plk1 were cloned into a PRCCMV vector and obtained from Dr. Eric Nigg's laboratory. HeLa cells were seeded at a concentration of 1 × 10 5/ml in 6-well plates (35 mm/well) and transfected using FuGENE 6 (Roche Applied Science) with GFP-centrin plasmid (0.5 μg) and wt Plk1 or T210D mutant Plk1(0.5 μg). GFP-Nek2 U2OS cells or U2OS cells were seeded in 10-cm dishes, transfected with wt Plk1 or T210D Plk1 plasmids (4 μg). After 24-48 h, cells are subjected for analysis.siRNA Interference—Double stranded ATM, Chk2 or Plk1 SMART-POOL siRNA oligonucleotides were purchased from Dharmacon Research (Lafayette, CO). Double-stranded siRNA oligonucleotides corresponding to firefly luciferase (Dharmacon) were used as controls. Oligofectamine (Invitrogen) was used to transfect HeLa and U2OS cells as specified by the manufacturers.Immunoprecipitation and Immunoblotting—Transfected cells were lysed in radioimmune precipitation assay buffer supplemented with proteinase inhibitors (20 mm p-nitrophenyl phosphate, 1 mm Pefabloc, 10 μg/ml pepstatin A, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, 5 μg/ml aprotinin). Cell lysates were incubated with anti-Myc antibody (Santa Cruz) or anti-GFP antibody (University of Alberta, Canada) overnight at 4 °C, followed by an additional 1-h incubation with Protein A-Sepharose beads (Santa Cruz). Immunocomplexes were washed three times with 1× phosphate-buffered saline. Western blot analysis was performed by loading samples on a 10% SDS/PAGE and transferring to nitrocellulose membranes (Invitrogen). Membranes were incubated with various antibodies, horseradish peroxidase-linked secondary antibody, and visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence reagents (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Rabbit polyclonal antibody against ATM and goat polyclonal antibody against Plk1 were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology.Immunofluorescence Staining—The cells were grown on coverslips, transfected, and cultured for 24-48 h before fixation. Cells were fixed and permeabilized with methanol for 2 min. After washing three times with 1× phosphate-buffered saline, coverslips were stained with mouse anti-myc antibody for 1 h at room temperature, followed by incubation with rhodamine-conjugated anti-mouse IgG secondary antibody for 1 h. Samples were mounted in 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole vectashield mounting medium (Vector Laboratories) and analyzed using fluorescence microscopy. Images were collected using a Hamamatsu digital camera and OpenLab software. Centrosome separation was assayed by counting GFP-centrin. Centrosomes were classified as separated if they were >2 μm apart from one another.In Vitro Kinase Assay—For Plk1 kinase assay, anti-myc immunoprecipitates were incubated with 0.5 mg/ml dephosphorylated casein in Plk1 washing buffer (20 mm Hepes,150 mm KCl, 10 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA,0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 5 mm NaF) supplemented with 10 μm ATP and 1 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP. For in vitro phosphorylation assay, anti-Plk1 immunoprecipitates were incubated with 100 ng of recombinant Nek2 protein in Plk1 washing buffer with 10 μm ATP and 1 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP. The reaction mixtures were incubated at 30 °C for 30 min and resolved on SDS-polyacrylamide gels. The gels were dried and subjected to autoradiography. The intensity of the bands was measured by AlphaImager 2200 program.PP1 Activity Assay—PP1 was immunoprecipitated with 5 μg of anti-PP1α monoclonal antibody (Santa Cruz) from protein samples. The immune complexes were then incubated with 30 μl of protein G plus agarose beads (Santa Cruz) washed three times with lysis buffer followed by Ser/Thr assay buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.0, 0.1 mm CaCl2). PP1 activity was assayed using a Ser/Thr phosphatase assay kit (Upstate Cell Signaling Solutions). The PP1 immune complex beads in 50 μl of Ser/Thr assay buffer were incubated with the phosphopeptide KRp-TIRR at 30 °C for 30 min. The beads were pelleted, and 25 μl of supernatant was analyzed for free phosphate in the malachite green assay by dilution with 100 μl of developing solution (Malachite Green). After incubation for 15 min, the release of phosphate was quantified by measuring the absorbance at 620 nm in a microtiter plate reader.RESULTSTo evaluate the role of Plk1 in the failure of centrosome separation after IR, we used a constitutively active mutant of Plk1 that is not inhibited after DNA damage. In this mutant, Thr-210 was changed to Asp (T210D) (39Lee K.S. Erikson R.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1997; 17: 3408-3417Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar). HeLa cells were transfected with myc-tagged wild type or constitutively active mutant (T210D) Plk1 plasmids and irradiated 24 h after transfection. Four hours after IR, cell lysates were assayed for Plk1 activity using β-casein as a substrate. Although the activity of wild type Plk1 decreased by 61%, the activity of the T210D Plk1 mutant remained unchanged, confirming that the activity of the T210D Plk1 mutant was not inhibited by IR (Fig. 1A) (27Smits V.A. Klompmaker R. Arnaud L. Rijksen G. Nigg E.A. Medema R.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 672-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (394) Google Scholar). To test the effect of Plk1 activity after IR on centrosome separation, we co-transfected wild type Plk1 or T210D Plk1 with GFP-centrin into HeLa cells. The GFP-centrin was expressed to allow easy visualization of the centrosomes and as a transfection marker. These cells were then synchronized with a thymidine block, followed by irradiated with 6 grays. Cells transfected with GFP-centrin alone were used as a control. Centrosome separation was assayed by microscopic evaluation of GFP-centrin in the transfected cells 12 h after release from the thymidine block (Fig. 1B). Centrosomes were classified as separated if they were >2 μm apart from one another. After partial synchronization, 40% of the cells in G2/M based on fluorescence-activated cell sorter analysis, and 58% of all cells had separated centrosomes (Fig. 1C). However, 60% of the irradiated, synchronized cells were in G2, whereas only 35% of all irradiated cells had separated centrosomes, consistent with our previous data showing that IR inhibits centrosome separation. Expression of wild type Plk1 produced similar results to those seen in control cells. Transient expression of the T210D Plk1 mutant in irradiated cells induced a similar frequency of separated centrosome to that seen in nonirradiated cells (51 and 54%, respectively), indicating that the constitutively active mutant of Plk1 overrode IR induced inhibition of centrosome separation.Because inhibition of Plk1 by DNA damage is ATM- or ATR-dependent (28van Vugt M.A. Smits V.A. Klompmaker R. Medema R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 41656-41660Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), we investigated the effect of ATM on centrosome separation after IR. It has been shown that caffeine can override the DNA damage checkpoint by direct inhibition of the checkpoint kinase ATM (40Blasina A. Price B.D. Turenne G.A. McGowan C.H. Curr. Biol. 1999; 9: 1135-1138Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (248) Google Scholar, 41Sarkaria J.N. Busby E.C. Tibbetts R.S. Roos P. Taya Y. Karnitz L.M. Abraham R.T. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 4375-4382PubMed Google Scholar). We therefore treated synchronized and irradiated GFP-centrin HeLa cells with caffeine and measured centrosome separation. As in figure 2A, without addition of caffeine, centrosomes were separated in 63% nonirradiated cells and 38% in irradiated cells. However, in the presence of caffeine, there was essentially no inhibition of centrosome separation by IR. To confirm that ATM affected the response of inhibition of centrosome separation by IR, we inhibited ATM expression in GFP-centrin HeLa cells using siRNA. There is an ∼30% decrease in ATM protein level showing by Western blot analysis (Fig. 2D). Fig. 2B indicates that there was a partial release from inhibition of centrosome separation in irradiated cells treated with siRNA against ATM. Because Chk2 is a downstream target of ATM and is known to mediate many functions of ATM, we examined the effect of Chk2 down-regulation on centrosome separation. Western blot analysis indicates nearly 80% suppression of Chk2 protein expression by siRNA against Chk2 (Fig. 2D). As shown in Fig. 2C, inhibition of Chk2 expression failed to affect centrosome separation in irradiated cells, excluding its role in the IR-induced inhibition of centrosome separation. We also show that down-regulation of Chk1 by siRNA has no effect on centrosome separation (Fig. 2C).FIGURE 2Inhibition of centrosome separation by IR depends on ATM not Chk2 or Chk1. GFP-centrin HeLa cells were treated with caffeine (A), siRNA against ATM (B), Chk1 or Chk2 (C), synchronized with a thymidine block, irradiated after release. Centrosome separation was determined by counting centrosomes stained with GFP-centrin. Centrosomes >2 μm were considered as separated. Values are given as the percentage of the cells with separated centrosomes ± S.D. for three independent experiments. Around 200 cells/experiment were counted. D, Western blot shows ATM, Chk2, and Chk1 expression after siRNA treatment. siRNA against firefly luciferase GL3 was used as a control.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Previously, we have shown that the kinase activity of Nek2 decreased in response to IR (15Fletcher L. J. 2000; 349: 509-518Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar), we tested whether Plk1 could phosphorylate Nek2 in vitro. We immunoprecipitated Plk1 in cells transfected with the kinase inactive K82R mutant, wild type, or T210D Plk1 plasmids using antibody against Plk1. The immunocomplex was incubated with recombinant Nek2 protein in kinase buffer containing γ-32P. Incorporation of γ-32P was seen as a band at 52 kDa in a 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel detected by autoradiography, indicative of Nek2 phosphorylation. The intensity of the bands was measured by AlphaImager 2200 program and plotted (Fig. 3A). Although Nek2 is autophosphorylated, expression of wild type or kinase active Plk1 increased Nek2 phosphorylation in vitro as seen in Fig. 3A.FIGURE 3Plk1 regulates the activity of Nek2. The immunocomplex was incubated with recombinant Nek2 protein in kinase buffer containing γ-32P. Incorporation of γ-32P into Nek2 was detected by autoradiography and the intensity of the bands was quantified by AlphaImager 2200 program. Nonspecific IgG antibodies served as immunoprecipitation controls. Phosphorylation was normalized with the control sample, and the result is a representative of two independent experiments. B, Plk1 promotes Nek2A degradation. Inducible GFP-Nek2A-U2OS cells were transfected with myc-tagged wt or T210D Plk1 plasmids. Four hours after GFP-Nek2A was induced by tetracycline, cycloheximide was added. Samples were collected at indicated time points and subjected to Western blot analysis. C, Plk1 interacts with Nek2A in vivo. Inducible GFP-Nek2A-U2OS cells were transfected with myc-tagged wt or T210D Plk1 plasmids. Tetracycline was added to induce GFP-Nek2A, and MG132 was added to prevent Nek2 degradation. Samples were collected and immunoprecipitated with antibody against myc or GFP. Immunoprecipitated proteins were resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE and immunoblotted (IB) with either anti-GFP or anti-myc antibody. D, Plk1 does not alter PP1α phosphatase activity. The large cytotoxins of Clostridia species glycosylate and thereby inactivate small GTPases of the Rho family. Clostridium difficile toxins A and B and Clostridium sordellii lethal toxin use UDP-glucose as the donor for glucosylation of Rho/Ras GTPases. In contrast, α-toxin from Clostridium novyi N-acetylglucosaminylates Rho GTPases by using UDP-N-acetylglucosamine as a donor substrate. Based on the crystal structure of C. difficile toxin B, we studied the sugar donor specificity of the toxins by site-directed mutagenesis. The changing of Ile-383 and Gln-385 in toxin B to serine and alanine, respectively, largely increased the acceptance of UDP-N-acetylglucosamine as a sugar donor for modification of RhoA. The Km value was reduced from 960 to 26 μm for the double mutant. Accordingly, the potential of the double mutant of toxin B to hydrolyze UDP-N-acetylglucosamine was higher than that for UDP-glucose. The changing of Ile-383 and Gln-385 in the lethal toxin of C. sordellii allowed modification of Ras in the presence of UDP-N-acetyl-glucosamine and reduced the acceptance of UDP-glucose as a donor for glycosylation. Vice versa, the changing of the equivalent residues in C. novyi α-toxin from Ser-385 and Ala-387 to isoleucine and glutamine, respectively, reversed the donor specificity of the toxin from UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to UDP-glucose. These data demonstrate that two amino acid residues are crucial for the co-substrate specificity of clostridial glycosylating toxins. The large cytotoxins of Clostridia species glycosylate and thereby inactivate small GTPases of the Rho family. Clostridium difficile toxins A and B and Clostridium sordellii lethal toxin use UDP-glucose as the donor for glucosylation of Rho/Ras GTPases. In contrast, α-toxin from Clostridium novyi N-acetylglucosaminylates Rho GTPases by using UDP-N-acetylglucosamine as a donor substrate. Based on the crystal structure of C. difficile toxin B, we studied the sugar donor specificity of the toxins by site-directed mutagenesis. The changing of Ile-383 and Gln-385 in toxin B to serine and alanine, respectively, largely increased the acceptance of UDP-N-acetylglucosamine as a sugar donor for modification of RhoA. The Km value was reduced from 960 to 26 μm for the double mutant. Accordingly, the potential of the double mutant of toxin B to hydrolyze UDP-N-acetylglucosamine was higher than that for UDP-glucose. The changing of Ile-383 and Gln-385 in the lethal toxin of C. sordellii allowed modification of Ras in the presence of UDP-N-acetyl-glucosamine and reduced the acceptance of UDP-glucose as a donor for glycosylation. Vice versa, the changing of the equivalent residues in C. novyi α-toxin from Ser-385 and Ala-387 to isoleucine and glutamine, respectively, reversed the donor specificity of the toxin from UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to UDP-glucose. These data demonstrate that two amino acid residues are crucial for the co-substrate specificity of clostridial glycosylating toxins. Jank T. Aktories K. Schulz G.E. J. Mol. Biol. 2005; 351: 973-981Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar) (Protein Data Bank identifier 2BVL). Based on this work we were able to identify amino acid residues that determine the co-substrate specificity of the toxins. Here we report on site-directed mutagenesis resulting in the change of the donor substrate specificity of toxin B and C. sordellii lethal toxin from UDP-glucose to UDP-GlcNAc. Vice versa, the donor specificity of the α-toxin from C. novyi was changed from UDP-GlcNAc to UDP-glucose. Materials—UDP-[14C]glucose (287.4 mCi/mmol), UDP-N-acetyl-d-[14C]glucosamine (288 mCi/mmol), and UDP-[14C]galactose (258 mCi/mmol) were obtained from PerkinElmer Life Sciences, and PCR primers were from Biochip Technologies (Freiburg, Germany). All other reagents were of analytical grade and purchased from commercial sources. Polymerase Chain Reactions—Amplification of the toxin fragments toxin-B546 of C. difficile VPI 10463, the fragment LT546 of C. sordellii 6018, and the fragment α551 of C. novyi type A strain ATCC 19402 were performed as described previously (7Hofmann F. Busch C. Prepens U. Just I. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11074-11078Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 15Busch C. Schömig K. Hofmann F. Aktories K. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 6378-6383Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Site-directed Mutagenesis of Toxin Fragments—The QuikChange™ kit (Stratagene), in combination with Pfu Turbo DNA polymerase, was used for the replacement of 1-5 nucleotides in the pGEX2T-LT546, pGEX2T-CN551, or pGEX2T-B546 plasmid. Primers were constructed as follows: toxin-B546 I383S (primer pair CDB_I383S), 5′-GTAAGGGTATTAGTAATCAAGGGCTAATTTC-3′ (sense) and 5′-GAAATTAGCCCTTGATTACTAATACCCTTAC-3′ (antisense); toxin-B546 I383G (primer pair CDB_I383G), 5′-GTAAGGGTATTGGAAATCAAGGGCTAATTTC-3′ (sense) and 5′-GAAATTAGCCCTTGATTTCCAATACCCTTAC-3′ (antisense); toxin-B546 I383S/Q385A (primer pair CDB_I383S/Q385A), 5′-GTAAGGGTATTAGTAATGCAGGGCTAATTTC-3′ (sense) and 5′-GAAATTAGCCCTGCATTACTAATACCCTTAC-3′ (antisense); toxin-B546 I383G/Q385A (primer pair CDB_I383G/Q385A), 5′-GTAAGGGTATTGGAAATGCAGGGCTAATTTC-3′ (sense) and 5′-GAAATTAGCCCTGCATTTCCAATACCCTTAC-3′ (antisense); LT546 I383S/Q385A (primer pair LT_ I383S/Q385A), 5′-CTCTGTTAGTAATGCAGCCTTAATTTC-3′ (sense) and 5′-GAAATTAAGGCTGCATTACTAACAGAG-3′ (antisense); and α551 S385I/A387Q (primer pair CN_S385I/A387-Q), 5′-GAAAAAAAACTTTTATCAATCAGTTTATAATTTC-3′ (sense) and 5′-GAAATTATAAACTGATTGATAAAAGTTTTTTTTC-3′ (antisense). Corresponding plasmids were selected in Escherichia coli XL1-Blue followed by transformation into E. coli BL-21 (DE3) (Invitrogen) for expression. Sequencing—All constructs and according variants of toxin-B546, LT546, and α551 were checked by sequencing with ABI PRISM™ dye terminator cycle sequencing ready reaction kit and ABI 310 cycle sequencer (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). Expression of Recombinant Proteins—Toxin fragments were expressed as GST fusion proteins from the E. coli expression vector pGEX-2T (Amersham Biosciences) as reported previously (7Hofmann F. Busch C. Prepens U. Just I. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11074-11078Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar). Affinity chromatography with glutathione-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences) was used for purification. Proteins were cleaved from a GST fusion protein with thrombin in TBP-150 elution buffer (100 μg/ml thrombin, 50 mm Tris-HCl, 150 mm KCl, and 10 mm β-mercaptoethanol, pH 7.5) for at least 1 h at 4 °C. Thrombin was removed by binding to benzamidine-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences). The recombinant GTP-binding proteins RhoA, Rac1, Cdc42, H-Ras, and RalA were prepared as GST fusion proteins as described (16Just I. Wilm M. Selzer J. Rex G. Von Eichel-Streiber C. Mann M. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 13932-13936Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (417) Google Scholar). Glycosylation Reaction—Recombinant GTP-binding proteins (50 μg/ml) were incubated with recombinant toxin fragments (5 μg/ml) and 10 μm UDP-[14C]sugars in a buffer containing 50 mm Hepes (pH 7.5), 100 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm MnCl2, and 100 μg/ml bovine serum albumin for indicated times at 37 °C. Total volume was 20 μl. Labeled proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE followed by phosphorimaging (Amersham Biosciences). Labeling of N-Acetylglucosaminylated Proteins—[14C]Galactosylation of GlcNAc-modified proteins was performed as described previously (13Selzer J. Hofmann F. Rex G. Wilm M. Mann M. Just I. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25173-25177Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). N-Acetylglucosaminylated GTP-binding proteins were transferred onto polyvinylidene difluoride membrane and galactosylated by 100 milliunits of β-1,4-galactosyltransferase (EC 2.4.1.38) in the presence of 10 μm UDP-[14C]galactose (1 μCi) by gentle agitation for 2 h at 25 °C. After extensive washing the blot slice was analyzed by phosphorimaging. UDP-Sugar Hydrolase Assay—UDP-sugar hydrolysis was performed as described (16Just I. Wilm M. Selzer J. Rex G. Von Eichel-Streiber C. Mann M. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 13932-13936Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (417) Google Scholar). Toxin fragments and mutants were incubated with 20 μm UDP-[14C]sugars and 100 μm corresponding unlabeled UDP-sugars in a buffer containing 50 mm Hepes (pH 7.5), 100 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 100 μm bovine serum albumin, and 100 μm MnCl2. Total volume was 20 μl. Samples of 1 μl were taken at each time point and subjected to thin layer chromatography with polyethyleneimine-cellulose plates (Merck) and 0.2 mm LiCl as mobile phase to separate the hydrolyzed sugar from UDP-sugars. The plates were dried and analyzed by PhosphorImager analysis. Quantification was carried out with ImageQuant (Amersham Biosciences). Determination of Km Values—Initial rate data for the glycosyltransferase reactions were determined by varying the UDP-sugar concentrations from ∼0.1-2 × Km. The experiments were performed with a fixed RhoA concentration of 130 μm. The Michaelis-Menten constants were obtained by computer-assisted analysis of Lineweaver-Burk plots of initial velocities from at least three independent experiments with the curve-fitting function in SigmaPlot (Systat Software, Inc.). Molecular Modeling of the Active Site of α-Toxin—Alignments of the catalytic domain of α-toxin from C. novyi (GenBank™ accession number Z48636) and toxin B (GenBank™ accession number X53138) were obtained using ClustalW. Energy minimization after the manual introduction of mutations according to the alignment was done using CNS (18Brunger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. Delano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16957) Google Scholar). Whereas toxin B uses UDP-glucose as a co-substrate, α-toxin from C. novyi only accepts UDP-GlcNAc (13Selzer J. Hofmann F. Rex G. Wilm M. Mann M. Just I. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25173-25177Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). Recently, the crystal structure of the catalytic domain of toxin B was solved (14Reinert D.J. Jank T. Aktories K. Schulz G.E. J. Mol. Biol. 2005; 351: 973-981Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1A). The catalytic cores of toxin B and α-toxin differ by only three amino acid substitutions, I383S, Q385A, and L519S (all numbered according to toxin B). Whereas Leu-519 interacts with the α-phosphate of the co-substrate, Ile-383 and Gln-385 are located near the C2 atom of the glucose moiety (14Reinert D.J. Jank T. Aktories K. Schulz G.E. J. Mol. Biol. 2005; 351: 973-981Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar), (Fig. 1B). Comparison of these residues within the group of clostridial glycosylating toxins (Fig. 1C) illustrates that Ile-383 and Gln-385 are conserved in all toxins with the exception of the α-toxin, which has serine and alanine residues at these positions as shown in Fig. 1B as a model. Therefore, we changed Ile-383 and Gln-385 to serine and alanine in a fragment of toxin B, which covers the catalytic domain (amino acid residues 1-546). We studied the modification of RhoA by this catalytic fragment in the presence of UDP-glucose or UDP-GlcNAc. Fig. 2A shows that the change of Ile-383 to serine slightly increased the labeling of RhoA in the presence of UDP-GlcNAc; accordingly, the kcat increased from 11 to 420 h-1 (see TABLE ONE). The same was true for exchanging Gln-385 to alanine; kcat increased to 514 h-1. Interestingly, the exchange of both residues largely increased the ability of toxin B to modify RhoA in the presence of UDP-GlcNAc (kcat at 2380 h-1). Immun. 2000; 68: 6378-6383Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholarb Below detectionc Not determined Open table in a new tab Because these two amino acids are located at the putative protein substrate recognition site in between β-strands 9 and 10, it was necessary to exclude an influence on protein substrate binding. Therefore we performed a glycosyltransferase reaction with members of the Rho and Ras family as protein substrates. Fig. 3 shows that RhoA, Rac, and Cdc42 were modified but, as expected, not H-Ras and RalA. The protein substrate recognition remained unchanged. To test whether UDP-GlcNAc was indeed attached to Rho proteins, we performed a second reaction with galactosyltransferase T, which transfers galactose from UDP-galactose exclusively onto N-acetylglucosamine but not onto glucose. Fig. 2B shows that after modification of RhoA by GlcNAc, the galactosyltransferase is able to modify RhoA by [14C]galactosylation. Concomitantly with the acceptance of UDP-GlcNAc as a co-substrate in the glycosylation of RhoA by the mutant toxin, the Km value for UDP-GlcNAc decreased. As shown in TABLE ONE, the Km value for UDP-GlcNAc was 960 μm for the wild-type toxin B fragment. With toxin-B I383S and Q385A the Km values decreased to 61 and 52 μm, respectively. For the double mutant (toxin-B546 I383S/Q385A), the Km value was reduced to 26 μm. Accordingly, these amino acid exchanges had major consequences for the glycohydrolase activity of the toxin fragment. Whereas the wild-type catalytic domain of toxin B cleaved UDP-glucose in the absence of protein substrate (Fig. 4A), UDP-GlcNAc was not hydrolyzed (Fig. 4B). By contrast, the double mutant of toxin B was capable of hydrolyzing UDP-GlcNAc (Fig. 4B). Next, we studied whether the exchange of the conserved residues Ile-383 and Gln-385 had the same consequences in C. sordellii LT. As mentioned above, LT accepts H-Ras and Rac but not RhoA as protein substrates (11Just I. Selzer J. Hofmann F. Green G.A. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10149-10153Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). Therefore, the modification of Ras by LT was studied. Fig. 5 shows that Ras was labeled by the wild-type fragment of LT with UDP-[14C]glucose but not with UDP-[14C]GlcNAc. However, the double mutant (LT1-546 I383S/Q385A) modified Ras in the presence of UDP-GlcNAc, whereas the labeling with radioactive UDP-glucose was significantly reduced. This change in donor substrate specificity was again corroborated by the glycohydrolase activity. As expected, only the double mutant is capable of hydrolyzing UDP-GlcNAc in the absence of a protein substrate (Fig. 4C). Finally, we studied the consequences of the exchange of the equivalent residues in C. novyi α-toxin, which accepts UDP-GlcNAc but almost no UDP-glucose (15Busch C. Schömig K. Hofmann F. Aktories K. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 6378-6383Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Within the catalytic active fragment of α-toxin (residues 1-551), Ser-385 and Ala-387 were changed to isoleucine and glutamine, respectively. Fig. 6 shows that these changes resulted in the labeling of Rho in the presence of UDP-[14C]glucose, whereas the labeling by UDP-[14C]GlcNAc was blocked. This change in the ability of α-toxin to use UDP-glucose was also reflected in changes in the Km values for the activated sugars (see TABLE ONE). Whereas the wild-type α-toxin fragment exhibited a Km value of ∼300 μm, this value was reduced to 4 μm for the double mutant. Again, the glycohydrolase activity of the double mutant proves the acceptance of UDP-glucose as co-substrate (Fig. 4E), whereas UDP-GlcNAc was not hydrolyzed by the double mutant (Fig. 4D). Members of the family of clostridial glycosylating toxins differ in their co-substrate specificity (3Schirmer J. Aktories K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2004; 1673: 66-74Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 4Just I. Gerhard R. Rev. Physiol. Biochem. Pharmacol. 2004; 152: 23-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar). Whereas C. difficile toxin A and B and also C. sordellii LT and hemorrhagic toxin use UDP-glucose as a donor substrate, α-toxin from C. novyi prefers UDP-GlcNAc and causes N-acetylglucosaminylation of their protein substrates (13Selzer J. Hofmann F. Rex G. Wilm M. Mann M. Just I. Aktories K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25173-25177Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar, 15Busch C. Schömig K. Hofmann F. Aktories K. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 6378-6383Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Here, we report the change of the co-substrate specificity of clostridial glycosylating toxins on the basis of the recently solved crystal structure analysis of toxin B (14Reinert D.J. Jank T. Aktories K. Schulz G.E. J. Mol. Biol. 2005; 351: 973-981Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). This study solved the three-dimensional structure of the catalytic domain of toxin B complexed with Mn2+ and the donor UDP-glucose, which was cleaved into UDP and glucose by the hydrolase activity of the toxin. The catalytic domain resembles the three-dimensional structure of a type A glycosyltransferase (20Bourne Y. Henrissat B. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2001; 11: 593-600Crossref PubMed Scopus (360) Google Scholar, 21Unligil U.M. Rini J.M. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2000; 10: 510-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (344) Google Scholar). Toxin B is a retaining glucosyltransferase. Because the close environment of the C1″ atom of glucose lacks any catalytic base and has nonpolar residues, a SNi mechanism rather than a double displacement reaction has been suggested to be responsible for the retaining transferase reaction of the glucose moiety onto the protein substrate RhoA (14Reinert D.J. Jank T. Aktories K. Schulz G.E. J. Mol. Biol. 2005; 351: 973-981Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). In close vicinity to the glucose moiety, several amino acid residues are found that are conserved within the family of clostridial glycosylating toxins. Interestingly, Ile-383 and Gln-385 are conserved in all UDP-glucose utilizing toxins, whereas the α-toxin, which uses UDP-GlcNAc, has a serine and alanine residue at these positions. Deduced from the crystal structure of toxin B, it has been suggested that UDP-GlcNAc would not be accommodated in the catalytic groove with residues Ile-383 and Gln-385 present (14Reinert D.J. Jank T. Aktories K. Schulz G.E. J. Mol. Biol. 2005; 351: 973-981Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). Therefore, we changed these residues in toxin B to those of α-toxin. Indeed, exchange of these residues increased the acceptance of UDP-GlcNAc as a donor substrate for toxin B with a decrease of the Km from ∼960 to 26 μm for the double mutant. These findings support the view that sterical hindrance is a major reason for the donor sugar specificity (illustrated as a model in Fig. 7). A comparable situation has been observed for the glycosyltransferases that define the specificity in human AB0(H) blood group biosynthesis. In this case, an N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferase (GTA) uses UDP-GalNAc to convert the H-antigen to the A-antigen, whereas a highly related transferase (GTB; only four residues differ) uses UDP-galactose to convert H-antigen into B-antigen. Only one amino acid residue (Leu-266 in GTA and Met-266 in GTB) located in the catalytic cleft is responsible for this difference in donor substrate specificity (22Patenaude S.I. Seto N.O. Borisova S.N. Szpacenko A. Marcus S.L. Palcic M.M. Evans S.V. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2002; 9: 685-690Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar). Moreover, a single point mutation (P234S) has been described recently that completely changes the GTB type (UDP-galactose) into an GTA type (UDP-GalNAc) (17Marcus S.L. Polakowski R. Seto N.O. Leinala E. Borisova S. Blancher A. Roubinet F. Evans S.V. Palcic M.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 12403-12405Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). Conformational changes involving the critical Met-266 residue were suggested as inducing these effects. Thus, minor change of the structural environment of the catalytic center can induce significant changes in the donor-substrate specificity. We also tested the consequences of changes of Ile-383 and Gln-385 in C. sordellii LT, which uses the same donor substrate as toxin B but a different protein substrate. Again, the I383S and Q385A mutations changed the co-substrate specificity from UDP-glucose to UDP-GlcNAc. Interestingly, in this case the substrate specificity was not only broadened but also reversed. This means that the affinity for UDP-glucose was reduced as compared with UDP-GlcNAc in the mutant. Finally, we were able to change the co-substrate specificity of the C. novyi α-toxin from UDP-GlcNAc to UDP-glucose by exchanging the equivalent residues Ser-385 and Ala-387 to isoleucine and glutamine, respectively. Again, this mutation resulted in a reversal of the specificity from UDP-GlcNAc to UDP-glucose. This suggests that sterical hindrance is not the entire reason for substrate specificity. Most likely, the exchange of the bulkier isoleucine and glutamine residues to serine and alanine provides additional interaction sites that may stabilize the binding of UDP-GlcNAc and increase its affinity toward the transferase. A similar mechanism has been suggested for the conversion of the sugar donor specificity in the blood group defining N-acetylgalactosaminyl-transferases (22Patenaude S.I. Seto N.O. Borisova S.N. Szpacenko A. Marcus S.L. Palcic M.M. Evans S.V. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2002; 9: 685-690Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar).

In this study, we describe a rapid immunoaffinity purification procedure for gel-free tandem mass spectrometry-based analysis of endogenous protein complexes and apply it to the characterization of complexes containing the SRm160 (serine/arginine repeat-related nuclear matrix protein of 160 kDa) splicing coactivator. In addition to promoting splicing, SRm160 stimulates 3'-end processing via its N-terminal PWI nucleic acid-binding domain and is found in a post-splicing exon junction complex that has been implicated in coupling splicing with mRNA turnover, export, and translation. Consistent with these known functional associations, we found that the majority of proteins identified in SRm160-containing complexes are associated with pre-mRNA processing. Interestingly, SRm160 is also associated with factors involved in chromatin regulation and sister chromatid cohesion, specifically the cohesin subunits SMC1alpha, SMC3, RAD21, and SA2. Gradient fractionation suggested that there are two predominant SRm160-containing complexes, one enriched in splicing components and the other enriched in cohesin subunits. Co-immunoprecipitation and co-localization experiments, as well as combinatorial RNA interference in Caenorhabditis elegans, support the existence of conserved and functional interactions between SRm160 and cohesin.

To gain a better understanding of how Crk II regulates the function of the Abl tyrosine kinase, we explored the function of the C-terminal linker and SH3 domain, a region of Crk II that is still poorly understood. Molecular modeling, tryptophan fluorescence, and covariation sequence alignment indicate that the Crk-SH3-C has a unique binding groove and RT loop not observed in typical SH3 domains. Based on these models, we made a series of mutations in the linker and in residues predicted to destabilize the putative binding pocket and RT loop. In Abl transactivation assays, Y222F and P225A mutations in the linker resulted in strong transactivation of Abl by Crk II. However, mutations predicted to be at the surface of the Crk SH3-C were not activators of Abl. Interestingly, combinations of activating mutations of Crk II with mutations in the highly conserved PNAY sequence in the SH3-C inactivated the activating mutations, suggesting that the SH3-C is necessary for activation. Our data provide insight into the role of highly conserved residues in the Crk-SH3-C, suggesting a mechanism for how the linker and the Crk-SH3-C function in the transactivation of the Abl tyrosine kinase.

p53 mRNA levels are tightly regulated during the cell cycle with its transcription being induced prior to DNA synthesis. However, the mechanism controlling this regulation is not well defined. Through characterizing an additional 1000 bp of upstream DNA sequences of the murine p53 gene, we identified new positive and negative regulatory elements. Furthermore, we found a trans-acting factor(s) that binds within a positive cis-acting element (-972/-953) in a manner indicative of regulation during the cell cycle. When Swiss3T3 cells are arrested by serum depletion p53 mRNA levels decrease and binding of this regulatory factor(s) to the promoter is reduced. Upon serum stimulation, the regulatory factor(s) binds the promoter and p53 mRNA levels increase prior to the cells entering S phase. When the factors are experimentally sequestered from the promoter or when the regulatory element is deleted from the promoter, p53 promoter activity is reduced. There is no further reduction in p53 promoter activity upon serum depletion and the kinetics of induction upon serum stimulation is delayed by approximately 5 h. These findings indicate that a factor(s) binding within the -972/-953 regulatory element on the p53 promoter is important for the proper regulation of p53 mRNA expression in response to mitogen stimulation. Our initial findings indicate that a member of the C/EBP family of transcription factors may play a role in this regulation.

β-Carotene has been identified as an intermediate in a secondary electron transfer pathway that oxidizes ChlZ and cytochrome b559 in Photosystem II (PS II) when normal tyrosine oxidation is blocked. To test the redox function of carotenoids in this pathway, we replaced the ζ-carotene desaturase gene (zds) or both the zds and phytoene desaturase (pds) genes of Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 with the phytoene desaturase gene (crtI) of Rhodobacter capsulatus, producing carotenoids with shorter conjugated π-electron systems and higher reduction potentials than β-carotene. The PS II core complexes of both mutant strains contain approximately the same number of chlorophylls and carotenoids as the wild type but have replaced β-carotene (11 double bonds), with neurosporene (9 conjugated double bonds) and β-zeacarotene (9 conjugated double bonds and 1 β-ionylidene ring). The presence of the ring appears necessary for PS II assembly. Visible and near-infrared spectroscopy were used to examine the light-induced formation of chlorophyll and carotenoid radical cations in the mutant PS II core complexes at temperatures from 20 to 160 K. At 20 K, a carotenoid cation radical is formed having an absorption maximum at 898 nm, an 85 nm blue shift relative to the β-carotene radical cation peak in the WT, and consistent with the formation of the cation radical of a carotenoid with 9 conjugated double bonds. The ratio of Chl+/Car+ is higher in the mutant core complexes, consistent with the higher reduction potential for Car+. As the temperature increases, other carotenoids become accessible to oxidation by P680+. β-Carotene has been identified as an intermediate in a secondary electron transfer pathway that oxidizes ChlZ and cytochrome b559 in Photosystem II (PS II) when normal tyrosine oxidation is blocked. As the temperature increases, other carotenoids become accessible to oxidation by P680+. A carotenoid molecule is an extended polyene chain with a variety of end groups and has been thought of as a “molecular wire,” because, in the one-electron oxidized form, or carotenoid radical cation, the hole is delocalized over the entire conjugated π-system. Carotenoid radical cations have recently been observed in several photosynthetic pigment-protein complexes, including PS II, 3The abbreviations used are: PS II, photosystem II;β-DM, n-dodecyl-β-d-maltoside; Car+, carotenoid radical cation; Car, carotenoid; Chl, chlorophyll; ChlZ, an oxidizable chlorophyll located at the periphery of the PS II reaction center; CP43, chlorophyll-binding protein encoded by psbC; CP47, chlorophyll-binding protein encoded by psbB; CrtI, purple bacterial phytoene desaturase (encoded by crtI); HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; MES, 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid; P680, first stable electron donor of PS II; Pds, cyanobacterial phytoene desaturase (encoded by crtP or pds); QA, primary quinone electron acceptor; QB, secondary quinone electron acceptor; WT, wild type; Zds, cyanobacterial ζ-carotene desaturase (encoded by crtQ or zds); Cyt b559, cytochrome b559.3The abbreviations used are: PS II, photosystem II;β-DM, n-dodecyl-β-d-maltoside; Car+, carotenoid radical cation; Car, carotenoid; Chl, chlorophyll; ChlZ, an oxidizable chlorophyll located at the periphery of the PS II reaction center; CP43, chlorophyll-binding protein encoded by psbC; CP47, chlorophyll-binding protein encoded by psbB; CrtI, purple bacterial phytoene desaturase (encoded by crtI); HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; MES, 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid; P680, first stable electron donor of PS II; Pds, cyanobacterial phytoene desaturase (encoded by crtP or pds); QA, primary quinone electron acceptor; QB, secondary quinone electron acceptor; WT, wild type; Zds, cyanobacterial ζ-carotene desaturase (encoded by crtQ or zds); Cyt b559, cytochrome b559. bacterial light-harvesting complexes LHC II, and recently in plant PsbS where they may have a role in non-photochemical energy quenching (1.Frank H.A. Brudvig G.W. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 8607-8615Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). Among photosynthetic reaction centers, carotenoid photooxidation is unique to PS II, which uses light energy to catalyze the oxidation of water to molecular oxygen. The process of water oxidation involves highly oxidizing species that can also oxidize a carotenoid molecule. Carotenoid radical cations have been identified as intermediates in the secondary electron transport pathway of PS II (2.Schenck C.C. Diner B. Mathis P. Satoh K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 680: 216-227Crossref Scopus (113) Google Scholar, 3.Hanley J. Deligiannakis Y. Pascal A. Faller P. Rutherford A.W. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 8189-8195Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 4.Tracewell C.A. Vrettos J.S. Bautista J.A. Frank H.A. Brudvig G.W. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 2001; 385: 61-69Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar, 5.Tracewell C.A. Cua A. Stewart D.H. Bocian D.F. Brudvig G.W. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 193-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar, 6.Telfer A. Frolov D. Barber J. Robert B. Pascal A. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 1008-1015Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Detergent-solubilized PS II core complexes contain up to 25 different integral membrane and extrinsic polypeptide subunits, including the D1/D2 complex and light-harvesting pigment-protein complexes CP43 (PsbC) and CP47 (PsbB). Light energy is absorbed by the chlorophyll-containing light-harvesting antenna and transferred to the primary donor chlorophyll(s) coordinated by the D1/D2 polypeptides. The term “PS II reaction centers” describes a structure that includes the D1 and D2 polypeptides, cytochrome b559 (Cyt b559), PsbI, and protein-bound cofactors that include six chlorophyll a (Chl a) molecules, two pheophytin a (Pheo a) molecules, a tightly bound plastoquinone (QA) and an exchangeable plastoquinone (QB). The primary photochemical reactions in PS II are initiated by the absorption of light energy by the primary chlorophyll donor (most likely chlorophyll BA) (7.Dekker J.P. Van Grondelle R. Photosynth. Res. 2000; 63: 195-208Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 8.Prokhorenko V.I. Holzwarth A.R. J. Phys. Chem. B. 2000; 104: 11563-11578Crossref Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 9.Diner B.A. Schlodder E. Nixon P.J. Coleman W.J. Rappaport F. Lavergne J. Vermaas W.F.J. Chisholm D.A. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 9265-9281Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar). The excited state of this chlorophyll drives charge separation, producing a reduced pheophytin (PheoA-) and a chlorophyll radical cation species, P680+. The charge separation is stabilized by transfer of the electron from PheoA- to QA, forming the state, P680+ QA-. Under normal physiological conditions, the very high potential oxidant, P680+, is reduced by electrons from the oxygen-evolving complex via a redox-active tyrosine (YZ). However, there are several conditions known, some of them of physiological relevance, in which the donation of an electron from the oxygen-evolving complex to P680+ is inhibited or retarded, allowing the highly oxidizing P680+ (EM ∼ 1.1-1.3 V) (10.Diner B.A. Rappaport F. Annu. Rev. Plant Biol. 2002; 53: 551-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar) to abstract an electron from other sources. ChlorophyllZ (ChlZ), Cyt b559, and carotenoid (Car) have been identified as electron donors to P680+ and are thought to comprise an alternate electron transfer pathway that has been suggested to protect PS II against uncontrolled oxidative reactions of the strong oxidant P680+. Cytochrome b559 and the ChlZ accessory chlorophylls (ChlZD1 and ChlZD2) are located at the periphery of the PS II reaction center (Fig. 1). Because these species can be oxidized by P680+ despite their location ≥30Å away, it has been postulated that β-carotene enables long distance electron transfer in PS II from Cyt b559 to P680+ by acting as an electron wire, forming an intermediate cation radical. Earlier studies suggested that the carotenoid molecule is the primary donor to P680+ at low temperature, followed by subsequent oxidation of ChlZ and Cyt b559 (3.Hanley J. Deligiannakis Y. Pascal A. Faller P. Rutherford A.W. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 8189-8195Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 5.Tracewell C.A. Cua A. Stewart D.H. Bocian D.F. Brudvig G.W. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 193-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). Recently, evidence has been obtained for the involvement of two carotenoid molecules in this pathway, most likely the all-trans-β-carotenes in the reaction center (6.Telfer A. Frolov D. Barber J. Robert B. Pascal A. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 1008-1015Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 11.Tracewell C.A. Brudvig G.W. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 9127-9136Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Although four crystal structures of PS II core complexes have been determined, the location of the carotenoids in the D1 and D2 polypeptides remains uncertain because of the limited resolution of the diffraction data, 3.2-3.8 Å (12.Zouni A. Witt H.T. Kern J. Fromme P. Krauss N. Saenger W. Orth P. Nature. 2001; 409: 739-743Crossref PubMed Scopus (1760) Google Scholar, 13.Kamiya N. Shen J.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 98-103Crossref PubMed Scopus (992) Google Scholar, 14.Ferreira K.N. Iverson T.M. Maghlaoui K. Barber J. Iwata S. Science. 2004; 303: 1831-1838Crossref PubMed Scopus (2845) Google Scholar, 15.Biesiadka J. Loll B. Kern J. Irrgang K.D. Zouni A. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2004; 6: 4733-4736Crossref Scopus (263) Google Scholar). Because of the snake-like structure of carotenoids, they are difficult to identify in the electron density, although a carotenoid was modeled in a very similar location in the D2 polypeptide in two of the structures. In two of the x-ray crystal structures, a second carotenoid was modeled in the D2 polypeptide, but with different orientations. No carotenoids have been modeled in the D1 polypeptide even though the accessory Chl ligated to His-118 in D1 (ChlZD1) can be photooxidized (16.Stewart D.H. Cua A. Chisholm D.A. Diner B.A. Bocian D.F. Brudvig G.W. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 10040-10046Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar), and a carotenoid located in the D1 subunit would supply a feasible pathway for electron transfer. However, a pathway for electron transfer from ChlZD1 to P680 through intermediate chlorophylls in CP43 has been suggested (17.Vasil'ev S. Brudvig G.W. Bruce D. FEBS Lett. 2003; 543: 159-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). The uncertainty in the location of the carotenoid molecules in the structure of PS II also means that the exact pathway of the alternate electron transfer is unknown. To increase our understanding of the role that carotenoids play in this electron transfer pathway, we decided to alter the carotenoid reduction potential and to study the effect of this alteration on the alternate pathway. The PS II reaction center binds two β-carotene molecules, which have 11 conjugated double bonds each (18.Kobayashi M. Maeda H. Watanabe T. Nakane H. Satoh K. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 138-140Crossref Scopus (132) Google Scholar, 19.Eijckelhoff C. Dekker J.P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1231: 21-28Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar). It is known that, as the number of double bonds of the polyene backbone increases, the wavelength maximum of the S2-S0 optical transition increases, and the molecule is easier to oxidize. Therefore, by decreasing the number of conjugated double bonds the carotenoid will be more difficult to oxidize, likely altering electron transfer through the secondary electron transfer pathway. There have been recent suggestions indicating that the reduction potential of P680+/P680 might be higher than previously thought (20.Rappaport F. Guergova-Kuras M. Nixon P.J. Diner B.A. Lavergne J. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 8518-8527Crossref PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar, 21.Cuni A. Xiong L. Sayre R. Rappaport F. Lavergne J. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2004; 6: 4825-4831Crossref Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Replacing β-carotene with a carotenoid that is more difficult to oxidize would also test the oxidative capacity of P680+. Exchanging cofactors in proteins has been demonstrated for many systems and has been useful in determining energy differences between redox cofactors. Extraction of carotenoids from PS II reaction centers has been demonstrated (22.Tomo T. Mimuro M. Iwaki M. Kobayashi M. Itoh S. Satoh K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1321: 21-30Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar). However, this extraction requires harsh conditions, resulting in the loss of Chl molecules. Reconstitution of carotenoids into solvent-extracted PS II and into carotenoid-less bacterial reaction centers has, however, been reported (23.Cox R.P. Bendall D.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1974; 347: 49-59Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 24.Agalidis I. Lutz M. Reiss-Husson F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1980; 589: 264-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 25.Farhoosh R. Chynwat V. Gebhard R. Lugtenburg J. Frank H.A. Photochem. Photobiol. 1997; 66: 97-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). A more gentle approach to this problem is to alter the carotenoid composition of PS II by changing the types of carotenoids available in vivo to be incorporated into the pigment-protein complex. As in green algae (26.Trebst A. Depka B. FEBS Lett. 1997; 400: 359-362Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar), we have found that cyanobacteria grown in the presence of carotenoid biosynthesis inhibitors do not assemble PS II, even in the presence of carotenoid supplements, presumably because the cells are unable to take up carotenoids from the growth medium. Therefore, this is not a viable method to replace β-carotene in PS II with another carotenoid. We show here that we can produce carotenoids that are not native to Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 by modifying the carotenoid biosynthetic pathway of this organism. We have learned what types of carotenoids can be incorporated into PS II. We have found that gene deletions that block β-carotene formation do not result in PS II formation (27.Bautista J.A. Rappaport F. Guergova-Kuras M. Cohen R.O. Golbeck J.H. Wang J.Y. Béal D. Diner B.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 20030-20041Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). However, expressing phytoene desaturase from Rhodobacter capsulatus in Synechocystis in place of the endogenous ζ-carotene and phytoene desaturases, results in the accumulation of carotenoids that can be incorporated into PS II. In this way, PS II core complexes from Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 can be genetically modified to produce carotenoids with fewer than 11 conjugated double bonds. Herein, we report the construction of Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 carotenoid mutants and characterization of PS II core complexes from the carotenoid mutant cells. Using low temperature visible and near-IR spectroscopy to detect the formation of new carotenoid radical cation species, we measure the formation and decay of the carotenoid and chlorophyll radical cations to probe the sequence of electron transfer steps in the secondary electron transfer pathway. Overall, these experiments provide new insight into the role of carotenoids in the secondary electron transfer pathways and assembly of PS II. Deletion Mutants—The genes for phytoene desaturase (pds) and ζ-carotene desaturase (zds) were deleted separately in the genome of the wild type (WT) Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 and replaced by a kanamycin resistance cassette. A PCR copy of the gene to be deleted (zds or pds) that included 500 bases upstream and downstream of the gene was ligated onto a pGEM-T plasmid vector (Promega A1360) using T4 DNA ligase and amplified in XL1-Blue Escherichia coli-competent cells (Stratagene 200249). These plasmids were named pA-zdsSyn or pB-pdsSyn, respectively. The 500 bases flanking each gene together with the ligated pGEM-T plasmid vector between them were copied by PCR using primers designed to give unique restriction enzyme sites to the termini of the PCR product. The PCR product was digested with the appropriate restriction enzymes and then ligated using T4 DNA ligase to a kanamycin resistance cassette with the same sticky ends as the PCR product. The final plasmid construct was then amplified in XL1-Blue E. coli-competent cells and used to transform the WT Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 strain. Single Replacement Mutant (Pdscap1)—The zds gene in the Synechocystis WT His tag strain (28.Lakshmi K.V. Reifler M.J. Chisholm D.A. Wang J.Y. Diner B.A. Brudvig G.W. Photosynth. Res. 2002; 72: 175-189Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar) encodes ζ-carotene desaturase (Zds), which converts ζ-carotene to lycopene, converted in turn by lycopene cyclase to β-carotene. This gene was replaced by the crtI gene of R. capsulatus, which encodes a phytoene desaturase, which converts phytoene to neurosporene, converted in turn by lycopene cyclase to β-zeacarotene (see below). This gene replacement should result (Fig. 2) in the loss of β-carotene expression with 11-double bonds and its replacement by β-zeacarotene with 9 conjugated double bonds. Plasmid pA-zdsSyn above was copied by PCR, excluding the zds gene using primers that gave unique restriction sites to the termini of the PCR product. The primers introduced a KpnI site in place of the gene ATG start codon and a XbaI site in place of the TAA stop codon. This PCR product was digested with the appropriate restriction enzymes and then ligated to PCR-amplified R. capsulatus crtI designed with the same sticky ends as the PCR product. The R. capsulatus crtI was derived from plasmid pGABX2 (29.Schmidt A. Sandmann G. Armstrong G.A. Hearst J.E. Boeger P. Eur. J. Biochem. 1989; 184: 375-378Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The primers introduced a KpnI site 100 bases upstream of the NCBI designated start codon for this gene and an XbaI site 24 bases downstream of the TGA stop codon. Following ligation, the new plasmid, called pA-crtIRhod, was then amplified in XL1-Blue E. coli-competent cells and digested with XbaI, which gave a single cut. A streptomycin resistance cassette with XbaI sticky ends was ligated into the cut plasmid using T4 DNA ligase. The final plasmid construct was then amplified in XL1-Blue E. coli-competent cells and used to transform the WT Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 His tag strain. Double Replacement Mutant (Pdscap2)—To more completely channel the conversion of phytoene to β-zeacarotene, the endogenous Synechocystis pds gene, still present in the single replacement mutant was also replaced with the R. capsulatus crtI gene. Plasmid pB-pdsSyn containing the Synechocystis pds gene was copied by PCR, excluding the pds gene, using primers that gave unique restriction sites to the termini of the PCR product. The primers introduced a KpnI site in place of the gene ATG start codon and an XbaI site in place of the TAA stop codon. This PCR product was digested with the appropriate restriction enzymes and then ligated to PCR-amplified R. capsulatus crtI as described above to give plasmid pB-crtIRhod. This plasmid was amplified in XL1-Blue E. coli-competent cells and digested with XbaI, which gave a single cut. A kanamycin resistance cassette with XbaI sticky ends was ligated into the cut plasmid using T4 DNA ligase. The final plasmid construct was then amplified in XL1-Blue E. coli-competent cells and used to transform Pdscap1. This gave a double replacement mutant with two copies of the R. capsulatus crtI gene. Transformation of Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 WT (His-tagged) 4His-tagged PS II refers to the presence of a hepahistidine tag located at the C terminus of CP47 (28.Lakshmi K.V. Reifler M.J. Chisholm D.A. Wang J.Y. Diner B.A. Brudvig G.W. Photosynth. Res. 2002; 72: 175-189Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). strain with the deletion and single replacement constructs made above was as described in Nixon et al. (30.Nixon P.J. Trost J.T. Diner B.A. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 10859-10871Crossref PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar). Successful transformants were selected on Petri plates containing BG-11 plus 5 mm glucose with 50 μg/ml kanamycin or 100 μg/ml streptomycin and grown in very dim light (∼0.1 μmol of photons m-2 s-1) at 30 °C. Antibiotic-resistant colonies representing successful transformants were replated seven times in BG-11 plus 5 mm glucose plates with 200 μg/ml kanamycin, for the deletion mutants or 100 μg/ml streptomycin, for the single replacement mutant, to obtain full segregation. Deletion mutations and single replacement mutation were confirmed by extracting total pigments from the cells and analyzing for the complete absence of β-carotene by HPLC. The cells were also unable to produce β-carotene under nonselective conditions (without kanamycin or streptomycin) indicating complete segregation. For the double replacement mutant, the fully segregated single replacement strain was subjected to another round of transformation, this time using plasmid pB-crtIRhod with a kanamycin resistance cassette ligated 5 bases after the stop codon of R. capsulatus crtI. The transformation procedure was the same as above except that incubation of the fully segregated single replacement strain with the plasmid construct was done in dim light (∼0.1 μmol photons m-2s-1). Wild-type Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 cells were grown in liquid BG-11 plus 5 mm glucose medium as described (31.Rögner M. Nixon P.J. Diner B.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 6189-6196Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32.Tang X.S. Diner B.A. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4594-4603Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar, 33.Rippka R. Deruelles J. Waterbury J.B. Herdman M. Stanier R.Y. J. Gen. Microbiol. 1979; 111: 1-61Crossref Google Scholar). The mutants were grown in BG-11 with 5 mm glucose in very dim light (∼1 μmol of photons m-2 s-1). Chem. 1990; 265: 6189-6196Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32.Tang X.S. Diner B.A. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4594-4603Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). The thylakoid membranes were suspended at a concentration of 1 mg/ml chlorophyll in Buffer A (25% glycerol, 20 mm CaCl2, 5 mm MgCl2, 50 mm MES, pH 6.0). After addition of a one-eighth volume of 10% (w/v) n-dodecyl-β-d-maltoside (β-DM), the suspension was stirred for 20 min and then centrifuged at 40,000 rpm in a 45-Ti rotor (Beckman-Coulter) for 10 min. The supernatant was then loaded onto a nickel-nitrilotriacetic acidagarose resin of ∼40 ml pre-equilibrated with Buffer B (Buffer A containing 0.03% β-DM) in a fritted column. The mixture was made 5 mm in imidazole by adding appropriate volumes of a 2 m imidazole stock solution and nutated in the dark at 4 °C for 30 min. Afterward, the column was drained and washed with 700 ml of Buffer C (Buffer A containing 0.1% β-DM and 5 mm imidazole). His-tagged PS II was eluted with 160 ml of buffer D (Buffer B containing 100 mm imidazole). The eluant containing PS II was made 1 mm in EDTA and concentrated in a Millipore concentrator utilizing a YM 100 Diaflo ultrafiltration membrane. The concentrated sample was then desalted by passing it through a gel filtration column (Econo-Pac 10 DG, Bio-Rad) pre-equilibrated with Buffer B then further concentrated in an Amicon Ultra-4 concentrator (Millipore) with a 100,000 molecular weight cutoff. The samples were then frozen in liquid N2 and stored at -80 °C until use. PS II core complexes were manganese-depleted for low temperature near-IR measurements. The complexes in Buffer B were diluted 1:1 with Buffer B containing 10 mm hydroxylamine and 2 mm EDTA, and incubated in the dark for 30 min. The samples were transferred to an Amicon Ultra-4 concentrator (Millipore) with a 100,000 molecular weight cutoff filter and centrifuged at 5,000 × g to reduce the volume to ∼100 μl. The sample was diluted twice to a volume of 4 ml with Buffer B containing 2 mm EDTA and concentrated to 100 μl. The Mn2+-depleted sample was diluted and mixed with glycerol and Buffer B to a final concentration of 63% glycerol, 20 mm CaCl2, 5 mm MgCl2, 0.03% β-DM, and 50 mm MES, pH 6.0. The chlorophyll content of the cells was determined by extraction with 100% methanol and using the 79.24 ml/mg extinction coefficient of Lichtenthaler (34.Lichtenthaler H.K. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 148: 350-382Crossref Scopus (9154) Google Scholar) at 665 nm. For total pigment analysis, PS II core complexes were extracted with a 50:50 acetone/methanol mixture under dim light. The mixture was centrifuged for 2 min (10,000 × g), and a 50-μl aliquot of the supernatant was immediately filtered (0.45 μm, Millex-LH polytetrafluoroethylene) and injected onto a reverse-phase HPLC column (Zorbax-ODS, 4.6 mm × 15 cm, Rockland Technologies) equilibrated with methanol:ethyl acetate (68:32, v/v). The separation was performed in isocratic mode using the same solvent system (35.Giorgi L.B. Nixon P.J. Merry S.A. Joseph D.M. Durrant J.R. De Las Rivas J. Barber J. Porter G. Klug D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 2093-2101Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar) at a flow rate of 0.25 ml/min for 60 min at room temperature. The relative chlorophyll and carotenoid concentrations were determined by measuring the area of their respective peaks in the HPLC chromatogram and dividing by the extinction coefficients according to Giorgi et al. (35.Giorgi L.B. Nixon P.J. Merry S.A. Joseph D.M. Durrant J.R. De Las Rivas J. Barber J. Porter G. Klug D.R. J. Biol. Birkhauser, Basel1995: 13-62Google Scholar). The eluted carotenoids were identified by their absorbance spectra using the diode array detector of the HPLC (Agilent Series 1100) and by their mobility using β-carotene and zeaxanthin standards. PS II core complexes were diluted to ∼10 μm Chl in a buffer containing 20 mm MES/NaOH (pH 6.5), 5 mm MgCl2, 20 mm MgCl2, 0.02% β-DM, 2 mm ferricyanide, and 65% glycerol. The sample (1.5. ml) was placed in a plastic cuvette with a 1-cm path length, inserted into a liquid nitrogen bath cryostat (DN 1704 from Oxford), and dark-adapted. The cryostat was then cooled to 77 K with liquid nitrogen and centered in the measuring beam of a Cary 1E UV-visible spectrophotometer (Varian) using a home-built cryostat holder. Spectra were recorded with data intervals of 0.1 nm, a scan speed of 60 nm/min, and a spectral bandwidth of 1 nm. The difference spectra were obtained by subtracting the absorbance spectrum in the dark-adapted state from those measured after 2-min illumination of the sample with continuous white light from a 200-watt halogen lamp. PS II core complex samples were prepared in a buffer containing 63% glycerol, 20 mm CaCl2, 5 mm MgCl2, and 50 mm MES (pH 6.0) and transferred to a plastic cuvette (Sigma) with a path length of 1 cm. The samples were treated with 100 μm potassium ferricyanide to oxidize Cyt b559, dark-adapted for 1 h, slowly frozen in a liquid nitrogen bath, and transferred to an Oxford Optistat cryostat mounted in a PerkinElmer Life Sciences λ-20 spectrophotometer. All experiments were performed on samples equilibrated at the specified temperature inside the Optistat for at least 1 h or until the baseline was stable. Samples were illuminated by a specified number of flashes at 532 nm from the second harmonic of an Nd:YAG Q-switched laser LAB-150-10 (Spectra-Physics) operating at 10 Hz. A beam splitter was used to vary the laser power delivered to the sample. A 1064 nm filter was also used to further reduce the level of first harmonic present in the laser beam. Typically, the flash energy was 150-180 mJ per pulse. The laser was coupled to the cryostat by a fiber optic cable (Schott-Fostec). Illumination of the sample by a series of pulses was achieved by manually triggering the laser Q-switch every 2-5 s, as specified below. In some cases, the laser Q-switch was triggered by a home-built laser controller device. The device is a counter that detects a transistor-transistor logic pulse from the laser indicating that the flash lamp has fired. After the specified number of flashes (or time since the laser operates at 10 Hz), the laser controller device triggers the Q-switch electronically. The total number of flashes and repetition rate (<10 Hz) can be specified by binary i

Exposure of cardiac myocytes to anoxia/reoxygenation (A/R) increases myocyte oxidant stress and converts the myocytes to a proinflammatory phenotype. These oxidant-induced effects are prevented by pretreatment of the myocytes with an oxidant stress (A/R or H2O2) 24 h earlier (oxidant tolerance). Although NF-kappaB and AP-1 (nuclear signaling) and Mn-SOD and eNOS (effector enzymes) have been implicated in the development oxidant tolerance, the precise relationship between the nuclear transcription factors and the effector enzymes in the development of oxidant tolerance has not been defined. Herein, we show that an initial A/R challenge results in nuclear accumulation of both NF-kappaB and AP-1 (EMSA). In addition, blockade of nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB (SN50) or AP-1 (decoy oligonucleotide) prevents the development of oxidant tolerance, i.e., the second A/R challenge produces the same quantitative effects as the initial A/R challenge. In this model, nuclear translocation of both NF-kappaB and AP-1 is required for induction of Mn-SOD, while nuclear translocation of AP-1, but not NF-kappaB, is a prerequisite for induction of eNOS. Collectively, our findings indicate that NF-kappaB and AP-1 work in concert to ensure the induction eNOS and Mn-SOD, which in turn are important for the development of oxidant tolerance.

The retinoblastoma (Rb) gene product is a tumor suppressor that is mutated or inactivated in many types of human cancers. Although Rb is known to be an upstream negative regulator of Abl protein tyrosine kinase, we propose here that Rb also functions as a downstream effector of Abl that plays a positive role in survival of Abl-dependent human tumor cells, including Bcr/Abl-positive chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). We show that Rb is constitutively phosphorylated at tyrosine in Abl-dependent tumor cells, and that Abl phosphorylates Rb specifically at Y805 within the C-terminal domain of the molecule. We also show that ectopic expression of Rb induces apoptosis in Abl-dependent tumor cells by inhibiting the Abl tyrosine kinase activity, and that Rb-induced apoptosis is compromised by Abl-catalysed phosphorylation of Rb at Y805. Furthermore, the silencing of endogenous Rb by RNA interference induced apoptosis in Abl-dependent tumor cells. Thus, our findings suggest that Abl-catalysed tyrosine phosphorylation of Rb is necessary for survival of Abl-dependent human tumor cells, and raises the possibility that this phosphorylated Rb can be a molecular target for cancer therapy aimed at inducing apoptosis of Abl-dependent tumor cells, such as Bcr/Abl-positive CML.

Phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis via the CDP-choline pathway is primarily regulated by CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase (CT) encoded by the Pcyt1a and Pcyt1b genes. Previously, we identified an Ets-1-binding site located at -49/-47 in the promoter of Pcyt1a as an important transcriptional element involved in basal CTα transcription (Sugimoto, H., Sugimoto, S., Tatei, K., Obinata, H., Bakovic, M., Izumi, T., and Vance, D. E. (2003) J. Biol. Chem. 278, 19716-19722). In this study, we determined whether or not there were other important elements and binding proteins for basal CTα transcription in the Pcyt1a promoter, and if other Ets family proteins bind to the Ets-1-binding site. The results indicate the formation of a ternary complex with Ets-1 binding at -49/-47 and Sp1 binding at -58/-54 of the Pcyt1a promoter that is important for activating CTα transcription. When nuclear extracts of COS-7 cells expressing various Ets family repressors were incubated with DNA probes, binding of Net to the probes was observed. Net dose-dependently depressed the promoter-luciferase activity by 98%, even when co-expressed with Ets-1. RNA interference targeting Net caused an increase of endogenous CTα mRNA. After synchronizing the cell cycle in NIH3T3 cells, CTα mRNA increased at the S-M phase corresponding to an increase of Ets-1 mRNA and a decrease of Net mRNA. These results indicated that Net is an important endogenous repressor for CTα transcription.
